comments:
I'm getting this error with Eclipse 3.3 on both Linux64 and Win32 using the PyDev plugin if I have the PyDev Package Explorer opened in the perspective.  I'm creating the bug report here because there's no trace of PyDev in the stack trace so I think the error is strictly in Eclipse.

There's a very similar bug, 191974, that claims to have this fixed but I tried the 07/02's linux64 nightly build with the same results.

In NavigatorContentService, the method getExtensions makes:

Collections.unmodifiableCollection(contentExtensions.values()), but that keeps the same collection underneath. A simple fix for Eclipse would be doing:

new ArrayList(contentExtensions.values()), as the unmodifiableCollection only guarantees that this view is not changed, but internally, the original map is still changed... (and as contentExtensions is private, the only place to change it is within the class)

If the method getExtensions was not final and contentExtensions was protected, it would be very simple to fix it as a client to make it work until the next release, but as that's not the case, trying to pre-load the extensions seems the only way to do it... still, I don't know how to achieve that correctly... (ideas?)

The primary issue here is that an extension is forcing the load of an extension in its restore state method. 

Can you provide some guidance on which extension in your environment is triggering another extension to load and why?

Actually, taking a second look at the trace, it seems that it's not within the PydevPackageExplorer that this is happening... In pydev, I've overriden createPartControl(Composite aParent), and that does not appear in it, so, it seems it's some other place that uses the CNF (also, I cannot reproduce it with only Eclipse and pydev).

Brian... could you give more specifics of which other plugins do you have and which views are available in pydev when this is happening (please try version 1.3.7 and see if the traceback had some change).

To debug this, start by disabling all extensions not shipped with Eclipse (Customize view .. Available Extensions). 

Then go through and enable them one at a time and run your test case. When the exception occurs, the last extension you enabled is the culprit.

From the pydev forum:
---------------------

Ok, reset back to fresh install and started loading packages one at a time,
starting with PyDEV.  PyDEV loaded fine and Eclipse restarted with no problems
with the PyDEV perspective at all.  Added Database Tools which required EMF
Tools, restarted and the problem appears.  I don't know if the compatibility
issue is with EMF or with the Database Tools, but that's where I got.

I retested using PyDev 1.3.7 on Suse Linux 10.1 64bit with the same error occuring.  Except this time the stack trace includes a pydev class in it,
PydevPackageExplorer.   This is different than what you were seeing Fabio.  I
double checked and PyDev 1.3.7 is installed 

This is using the stock Eclipse SDK build of Eclipse 3.3 with no other plugins/extensions installed other than what came with it, 
'eclipse-SDK-3.3-linux-gtk-x86_64.tar.gz'.  That doesn't contain any database tools in it but it does have the JDT and PDE extensions.

Brian

I just downloaded the 'Eclipse 3.3 Platform' which doesn't contain the JDT or PDE plugins, just the base IDE.  I then installed PyDev 1.3.7, restarted Eclipse, opened the PyDev perspective, shutdown and restarted Eclipse.  Same error and stack trace as my last message.  Same OS, etc.

Brian

More so than the plugins, what you might try focusing on is the extensions selected in the "Customize View.." dialog. By checking and unchecking these items, we can identify the specific extension that's causing the problem.

Basically, one extension in your environment is forcing one or more other extensions to load, which modifies the set of loaded extensions, which causes the concurrent modification exception. 

I thought this might be related to the same extension that caused bug 189635, but if you have no database extensions loaded, then it must be something specific to a PyDev extension. Are there any calls in the content providers or label providers that calls back into the content service?
Michael, I can't find any 'Customize View' dialog.  Do you mean 'Customize Perspective' instead?  And if so, are the extensions represented by the 'Commands' tab?

If 'Custom Perspective' | Commands is what you were referring to, disabling the commands didn't help. I created a new perspective with just the 'Pydev Package Explorer' view in it, disabled all commands, and still got the same error.

Created an attachment (id=73478)
The Customize View dialog

In the Pydev Package Explorer view, I disabled "Pydev Navigator Content" under Customize View... --> Content, and now I don't get the concurrent modification error when Eclipse starts up in the Pydev perspective. The only other content left enabled there is "Resources".

Now that the view's not crashing, I notice that when the view is first drawn, its tree widget appears for a couple of seconds, then briefly disappears and returns again, even though I don't have workspace refreshing enabled at startup. Not sure if this is a clue.
I get the same results as Alex.

Then it must be something specific to the PyDev extension. 

Are there any calls in the content providers or label providers that call back into the content service (particularly from the restoreState() implementations)?

The expansion must be causing one or more extensions to load. It may have been, that by coincidence, the last version didn't have any extensions to load or all that were required were already loaded at the time of this call. Because of changes in their enablement expressions or new extensions, that is no longer the case. 

It seems that this can be fixed by removing that call. We can examine another approach for you to restore the selection in the viewer once loaded.

I'll change it in pydev to do nothing in the restore and only do the actual restore after the part is completely created... 

I guess that the exception could still be raised if I do a restore at that point, but at least I can treat it correctly there. I'll give you more details once I'm able to do the build.

I'm also getting this error with Eclipse 3.3 and Java 1.6 (on Linux). As soon as use Java 1.5 to run Eclipse the error disappears.

Cheers,
Reto

Well, I've tried reproducing it here and couldn't do it... but I'm on java 1.5, so, maybe java 1.6 has something to do with it (is everyone with this error using java 1.6?)

I've already made a fix to pydev that should be released next week that should have a workaround for that (but as I couldn't reproduce it here, it may still have other problems) -- I'll give java 1.6 a try to see if I'm able to reproduce it then.

(In reply to comment #20)
> Well, I've tried reproducing it here and couldn't do it... but I'm on java 1.5,
> so, maybe java 1.6 has something to do with it (is everyone with this error
> using java 1.6?)

Affirmative here, using sun-jdk-1.6.0.02 (1.6.0.01 before today) on Gentoo amd64.
Yes, using 1.6 latest on WinXP Pro here.

Interesting. I flipped over to sun-jdk-1.5.0.12 and launched Eclipse a couple of times, but wasn't able to replicate this bug. Flipping back to 1.6.0.2 again, the bug still happens every time at launch.

By the way, I always launch the Eclipse binary with the -vm option pointing to my JDK's java binary because that seems to be the only way to make Eclipse 3.3's new launch behavior under Linux do what it's supposed to do.

Ok, I've tried with java 1.6 and was able to reproduce the bug (maybe it happens because of a different scheduling of threads?) -- and make a workaround for it... basically, in pydev the tree will not have its state restored at the default framework call, only later when I'm able to treat that exception, so, the 1st time it is called, that exception is treated and a second call will make it actually restore the state of the tree (so, it's really only a workaround).

I guess the actual fix still needs to be addressed in Eclipse... Michael?
Mike -- will you consider this bug for 3.3.1?

Created an attachment (id=76401)
Protects against extensions which load other extensions in their restoreState()
Fabio, would you try the patch in your environment?
Released the patch for 3.3.1
